body.p: Geraldine Bates is a senior Specialist Speech and Language Therapist working with children and young people with communication difficulties attending a primary language resource base. She has links with the Speech and Language Therapy Research Unit in Bristol and has worked as a Research Assistant at the University of the West of England on a project exploring vocabulary development in bilingual children. She has a particular interest in group intervention for children with social communication difficulties and/or autism, and exploring functional social outcomes for this group of children.

Pamela Baylis obtained her PhD in Psychology in 2005. A qualified special educational needs teacher, she worked in British inner-city special and primary schools. After obtaining a specialist dyslexia teaching diploma she worked as a research assistant at the Centre for Reading and Language, University of York, UK.

Richard Body is a Senior Lecturer in the Department of Human Communication Sciences at the University of Sheffield, UK and is a qualified Speech and Language Therapist. His academic interests include clinical linguistics and traumatic brain injury, with a particular focus on the detailed analysis of real interactions.

Jeri A Carroll is Professor of Elementary and Early Childhood Education at Wichita State University, USA, and has scholarly interests in curriculum for young children, assessment in teacher education, and higher education program design. She currently teaches in the MEd in Curriculum and Instruction and the MAT in Early Childhood Unified.

Shula Chiat is Professor of Child Language at City University London, UK and an Honorary Fellow of the Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT). She has taught on speech and language therapy courses since the 1980s, and has carried out and collaborated in research on developmental and acquired language impairments. She is author of a book on children with language problems, and has co-authored a linguistics text for clinicians.

Tony Cline is Co-Director of the CPD Doctorate in Educational Psychology at University College London, UK. His research interests include the education of bilingual and minority ethnic children, the analysis of school ethos, and changing perspectives on child development. He is co-author of the textbook Special educational needs, inclusion and diversity (Open University Press).

Maike Feuerstein completed an MSc in Speech and Language Sciences at University College London, UK and works with Royal Liverpool and Broadgreen University Hospitals NHS Trust, UK. She contributed to this research while studying for an MSc in Psychology of Language and Communication at the University of Bristol.

James Law is a Speech and Language Therapist and Professor of Speech and Language Science at Newcastle University, UK. His research interests include the evaluation of interventions related to children with speech and language impairment, the overlap between communication difficulties and mental health, and the analysis of secondary longitudinal data. At the time of the article published in this issue of Child Language Teaching and Therapy he was Director of the Centre for Integrated Healthcare Research at Queen Margaret University, Edinburgh and head of the Nuffield Speech and Language Review Group.

Glynis Laws is an Honorary Senior Research Fellow in the Department of Experimental Psychology, University of Bristol, UK. Her research interests include language and cognitive development of children with Down syndrome and children with specific language impairment.

Kimberly McDowell is Associate Professor of language and literacy at Wichita State University, USA, and a licensed speech-language pathologist. She has scholarly interests in emergent literacy, speech–sound disorders, and teacher professional development. She currently is the Program Chair for the MAT in Early Childhood Unified and the Reading Specialist programs.

Emily Mason-Apps is a final year PhD student at the University of Reading, UK. Her research is entitled ‘Precursors to speech and language in typically-developing infants, and infants with Down syndrome’. Prior to this she worked as a part-time Research Assistant at the University of Bristol where she had completed her first degree, before moving to the University of Reading to do a Masters in Developmental Psychopathology.

Gill Matson is Honorary Research Assistant at University College London, UK and an independent Educational Psychologist who has specialized in speech, language and communication needs. She previously worked as an educational psychologist both for local authorities and also on the staff of two specialist language schools.

Tom Muskett is a Lecturer in the Department of Human Communication Sciences at the University of Sheffield, UK. He is a qualified Speech and Language Therapist with a particular interest in the applications of Conversation and Discourse Analysis to psychological and clinical research and practice.

Mick Perkins is Emeritus Professor of Clinical Linguistics in the Department of Human Communication Sciences at the University of Sheffield, UK. He has published widely both in his specialism of clinical linguistics and also in areas such as pragmatics, semantics and language development.

Charlene C Plunkett graduated in 2010 as a clinical associate from the MSc in Applied Psychology for Children and Young People at The University of Edinburgh. Currently employed within the NHS Greater Glasgow & Clyde health board, she is working in the area of early intervention for mild to moderate mental health problems in children and young people.

Tim Pring is Professor of Research in Speech and Language Therapy at City University London, UK. He is an Honorary Fellow of the RCSLT and a research advisor at ICAN, London, UK. He has published articles in many areas of speech and language therapy and is particularly interested in the treatment of children with speech, language and communication needs.

Belinda Seeff-Gabriel is a Clinical Tutor in Speech and Language Therapy at City University London, UK, and is an honorary lecturer at University College London, UK. She has a PhD in developmental speech disorders. She has published articles and an assessment related to her particular interest: the co-occurrence of speech and language difficulties.

Maggie Snowling is Professor of Psychology at the University of York, UK and is a Chartered Clinical Psychologist. She served on Sir Jim Rose’s Expert Advisory Group on provision for Dyslexia (2009) and was an expert member of the Education for All: Fast Track Initiative group in Washington, DC, USA (2011).

Helen Stringer is a Speech and Language Therapist and Lecturer in the Department of Speech and Language Sciences in the School of Education, Communication and Language Sciences at Newcastle University, UK. She has a specialist research interest in developing interventions to ameliorate speech disorder in children and is particularly interested in ascertaining the impact of phonological intervention for children with social, emotional and behavioural difficulties.

Alison Tempest is Senior Lecturer and the Programme Lead for the undergraduate SLT programme at De Montfort University, Leicester, UK. Her interests include early years, speech difficulties and working with agencies, such as the police and youth offending services to support young people with speech, language and communication difficulties.

Bill Wells is a Professor in Human Communication Sciences at the University of Sheffield, UK. His research with children – both with and without speech difficulties – draws on two complementary approaches: the analysis of naturalistic talk-in-interaction, using Conversation Analysis, and psycholinguistic profiling, using a framework developed in collaboration with Joy Stackhouse.

Catherine White is a Community Learning Facilitator for MacIntyre, developing bespoke educational programmes for young adults with autism, with emotional and behavioural disorders, and with severe learning difficulties in Oxfordshire, UK. She contributed to this research during a professional placement at the University of Bristol in the course of completing a psychology degree at Cardiff University.
